author: Staff Reporter
text:
Voter awareness stickers pasted on town buses

A total of 1,150 booth-level teams had been constituted in the district to create awareness among voters of the importance of voting and their democratic right, said Collector T.N. Hariharan.

Distributing awareness pamphlets at Kamarajar central bus stand here on Thursday, he said that each team, comprising three members, including a booth officer and a Village Adminitrative Officer, would campaign among voters within its polling station limits.

Besides, campaign had been intensified in all places in urban and rural areas. A propaganda van fitted with a giant screen was also parked at the central bus stand to enlighten people on the need to vote. Awareness stickers were pasted on town buses in the bus stand.

Theni

Collector N. Venkatachalam said that 41 non-governmental organisations working in the rural areas were roped in to motivate all persons aged 18 years and above to enrol their names in the voter list.

They would meet people residing in remote villages and interact with them on the importance of voting.

They would also undertake door-to-door verification and ensure that all names were included in the voter list.

An SMS could be sent to 1950 to check names in the electoral roll.

Those who could not enrol their names in the voter list could do so online.

The NGOs could inform the control room through toll-free number 18004257028 any deficiency in basic amenities in polling stations for immediate action, the Collector added.

He also advised the NGOs to hand over the excess wheelchairs they had for election duty.
title: 1,150 booth-level teams in Dindigul district
